title.narrative: PREVENTION, DIAGNOSIS AND MONITORING OFMALNUTRITION

description.narrative: The health system has improved capacity to adequately prevent, diagnose, and monitor all forms of malnutrition in children and adolescents., which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition In Early Childhood (Covid), Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, child and adolescent malnutrition in all its forms is reduced, with a special focus on overweight and obesity.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: The health system has improved capacity to adequately prevent, diagnose, and monitor all forms of malnutrition in children andadolescents.

description.narrative: UNICEF’s advocacy and technical support to the Ministry of Health;resulted in the development of a National Strategy on the Prevention of All Forms of Malnutrition during the First 1,000 Days, which was previously neglected. Key national norms, regulations and bylaws were strengthened to protect and promote breastfeeding and are awaiting publication. A national innovative campaign to promote breastfeeding in a family friendly workplace reached almost 5,000,000 caregivers. An emergency response to provide health and nutrition care to migrant and displaced children and women was started in three border cities: Tijuana, Ciudad Juarez and Tapachula, reaching 700 children and caregivers. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:26/01/2022

baseline.value: International Code of marketing of breastmilk substitutes partially adopted

target.value: 2025:International code of marketing of breastmilk substitutes enforced benefiting all children under 2 years in Mexico (4 million children)

actual.value: 2021: Work agenda to strengthen the compliance of the Code agreed with the Government; Presidential decree declaring the obligation to comply with the Code drafted; and Regulation of Sanitary Control of Products and Services improved (awaiting for pubblication
